spectrum as was obtained with the enantiopure ligands. Using a

) and their enantiomeric pairs). However, in
both cases, only one set of signals is observed, which is a strong
indication that only one species with high symmetry is formed
by chiral self-sorting without any sign of the formation of dia-
stereomeric mixtures. To further confirm the self-sorting behav-
ior of these cage structures, CD spectroscopy was performed. A
linear dependence of CD amplitude on the ee of ligand stable
was found, which can be expected when the homochiral en-
cally active species in solution (Figure S1, Supporting Informa-
Additionally, DOSY NMR spectroscopy revealed that the
signals correspond to a single type of assembly in each case
(see Supporting Information File 1, section 2). The measured
CN at 23 °C) can be translated into hydrodynamic radii of
by using the Stokes–Einstein equation [54]. By means of
ESI high-resolution mass spectrometry, we were able to verify
constitution of both cages. The HRMS spectrum of
shows the signals for the cations [Pd
, the peaks corresponding to the cations [Pd
(Figure 3). For both isomers, the experimental isotopic patterns
was grown by vapor diffusion of a 1:1 mixture of benzene and
diethyl ether into a solution of the cage in a 1:1 mixture of
acetonitrile and chloroform. The crystal structure shows cage
ion and one molecule of acetonitrile located inside each cage. In
addition, a chloride ion is located close to the metal centers
outside of the cage. This counterion most likely originates from
the solvent, as chloroform can contain considerable amounts of
HCl. The additional anions required to balance the charge of the
cage could not be unambiguously located in
the difference Fourier map (see Supporting Information File 1
for details). The structure belongs to the
the unit cell is occupied by a pair of enantiomeric cages in
